text: William Orville Douglas (October 16, 1898January 19, 1980) was an American jurist and politician who served as an associate justice of the Supreme Court of the United States from 1939 until 1975. He was known for his strong progressive views. He is seen as the Supreme Court's most liberal justice ever, and supported expanding individual rights on a number of fields. So far, he served the longest time of any justice, and wrote the most opinions. Finally, Douglas was forced to retire in 1975 after a severe stroke. He was previously a politician for the Democratic party and several influential liberals wanted him for vice president alongside Franklin D. Roosevelt for the 1944 presidential elections. ==References== Category:1898 births Category:1980 deaths Category:Members of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission Category:United States Supreme Court justices Category:Politicians from Minnesota Category:American progressives Category:Democratic Party (United States) politicians
title: William O. Douglas
